Agrees to work with Gordon after pressure, despite visible misery.
Listens attentively to Gekko's explanation of wealth and power dynamics, acknowledges understanding with 'Obviously...'
Agrees to join Gekko despite feeling confused and drained, showing willingness to engage with complex moral and strategic challenges
Expresses hesitation and inability to commit to a social invitation ('I can't make it tonight.'), indicating possible overwhelm or lack of social confidence in this moment
Admits to being hurt and betrayed openly to Darien; shows vulnerability in front of her.
Slumps on the couch drinking tequila and smokes in visible distress, allowing his close companion to see his broken state.
Uses crude language and expresses strong frustration and anger about being betrayed.
Refuses to blame Darien and accepts her empathy, engaging sincerely in their conversation.
Admits he has been played by Gekko and acknowledges the crash and liquidation of Bluestar.
Remains evenly determined to not let Bluestar's destruction happen despite the setback.
Refuses to 'pull the trigger' on a hostile take-over that would hurt the town, showing concern for others.
Lashes out at Darien when feeling hurt and rejected, accusing her of being 'the best money can buy.'
Refuses to 'pull the trigger' on a hostile takeover, showing moral resolve and recognition of consequences.
Dismisses Darien's warnings about Gordon Gekko, underestimating the risks involved.
Expresses confidence in surviving without Gordon Gekko's backing, demonstrating self-assurance.
Engages in emotionally charged argument, escalating conflict instead of seeking resolution.
Reacts with anger to Darien, tells her to leave and changes the locks.
Stares numbly at the closed door, showing devastation and vulnerability.
Cuts off Sylvie abruptly and demands fast sale of his condo, showing impatience.
Steps across angrily, yells and demands Darien to leave, changes locks impulsively.
Stares numbly and silently at the closed door, showing devastation and loss.
Orders realtor to sell condo fast, cuts her off impatiently, appears unshaven, smoking, looking like he has been on a bender.
Enters office later with a serious, purposeful look in his eye.
Runs urgently to hospital after hearing about his father's heart attack, showing concern.
Lightly jokes with his hospitalized father despite the serious situation, indicating an attempt to comfort and connect.
Shows somewhat dismissive or distracted behavior when first approached by Carolyn and Janet, ignoring the tone in Carolyn's voice.
Walks in with a purposeful, serious look, immediately takes charge by instructing Janet to urgently get his father and union reps on the phone.
Quickly senses urgency and responds with immediate concern when told his father had a heart attack, running out to the hospital.
Drives fast through traffic to reach hospital promptly, showing determination and urgency.
Lighting a cigarette upon arrival at the hospital, possibly indicating stress or trying to maintain composure.
Attempts to lighten mood with a casual joke in hospital room despite serious condition of his father, showing emotional coping but possibly underestimating severity.
Expresses deep love and remorse to his sick father, openly weeps, and sincerely praises him.
Acknowledges the harm caused by Gekko and shows concern for his father's legacy and the airline.
Attempts to soothe his father's anger and earn his trust, asking to speak on his behalf to the unions.
Expresses sincere emotions and admits past mistakes to his father, showing emotional intelligence and self-awareness.
Calmly explains a complex plan to save the airline and asks for his father's trust and authority to negotiate with unions, demonstrating confidence and strategic thinking.
Fumbles with cigarette nervously when stressed, indicating a momentary lapse in composure.
Engages with union representatives in a cooperative strategy against a common threat, showing willingness to collaborate with diverse people.
Uses insider information vaguely and pointedly, indicating a certain secrecy and manipulative tendency in dealings.
Explains a complex stock manipulation strategy to union reps with confidence and clarity.
Claims to have insider information and uses it to predict stock movements confidently.
Leads a diverse and unlikely group to secure a critical meeting with an influential figure.
Expresses sincere concern for the airline's success and wants to see it work rather than just profit from it.
Admits to Marv that he has been a 'schmuck' lately and wants to make it up to him by involving him and his clients in a good deal.
Proposes a sophisticated investment strategy to Sir Lawrence involving union concessions and positioning against Gordon Gekko.
Demonstrates knowledge of regulatory concerns by acknowledging the difference between raiding and insider trading.
Shows willingness to negotiate and address contract stipulations such as iron-clad agreements.
Admits to personal mistakes to Marv and takes responsibility for recent failures.
Attempts to regain trust and loyalty from Marv by involving him and his clients in the Bluestar investment.
Suggests Lou Mannheim put all his clients' money into Bluestar Airlines despite Mannheim's visible physical hardship and reservations.
Hears Mannheim's concerns but simply walks on without engaging further or offering comfort.
Commands brokers to unload Bluestar stock quickly as it peaks, initiating a panic sell.
Accurately reports market situation from Gekko to Larry Wildman, switches phone lines efficiently to manage communications.
Advises Gekko not to get emotional about stock and gives clear, professional advice under pressure.
Urgently pushes Gekko to make a decision as stock price is falling, showing responsibility and concern for client's losses.
Maintains professionalism despite Gekko's harsh language and pressure.
Smiles at the receptionist Carolyn and says, 'Smile, there's justice in the world...'
Notices awkward silence and cold interactions from coworkers but does not confront or inquire further.
Politely engages with Mannheim despite internal impatience.
Cuts off Janet when she attempts to talk to him.
Cuts off Janet before understanding what she wants to tell him.
Responds politely to Mannheim's warning but does not fully grasp its meaning.
Has been expecting the SEC investigation and arrest, showing some awareness of consequences.
Does not defend himself or retaliate while being physically assaulted by Gekko.
Looks away and says nothing during confrontation, internalizing conflict without escalating it.
Accepts handkerchief from Gekko and staunches his own bleeding quietly, showing restraint and no aggression.
Reflects thoughtfully on his identity and relationship to Gekko, showing sincerity and self-awareness.
Looks at Gordon, wanting to say more but holds back, indicating conflicted emotions and reluctance to hurt.
Walks past the doorman and diners with bloody nose and mud, showing no arrogance or entitlement despite appearance.
Suffers discomfort from tape removal without complaint, showing stoicism but no explicit warmth.
Complies with investigators and allows tape to be played for evidence, indicating cooperation and responsibility.
Staunches the flow of blood from his nose and walks confidently into a restaurant despite being battered and disheveled.
Consciously decides to separate himself from Gordon Gekko, acknowledging his own identity and limits rather than blindly emulating someone else.
Carries and uses a hidden tape recorder to gather evidence against Gekko, showing forethought and strategic thinking.
Does not verbally confront Gekko fully or express his thoughts explicitly, stopping himself before saying more.

Admits to being nervous and acknowledges likely jail time, indicating realistic self-awareness and acceptance of consequences.
Family reflects positively that he told the truth and returned the money, indicating some ethical acknowledgment and responsible behavior despite mistakes.
Admits to not liking himself and feeling isolated as a convicted felon.
Moves closer to Darien, showing longing, hope, happiness, and forgiveness.
Acknowledges the severity of his situation and expresses self-awareness about his impending jail time.
Responds ironically and with self-deprecation when asked about friends supporting him, showing low self-confidence.
Despite his situation, he shows openness to emotional connection and forgiveness, indicating emotional intelligence but not directly competence in skill or confidence.
